reviews.review_text: It’s not easy to even start talking about Cave Story without starting to throw out such adjectives like “modern classic” or “cult underground hit”. But there, you have it, I just wrote it and I won’t take it back. This game preceded the current state of indie scene by a few years, back when it was released as freeware title in 2004. In a few years it was improved and expanded to various platforms with more content and refined graphics. It even was remade in 3D and published for 3DS, though that particular version lacks to provide definitive Cave Story experience. But in the beginning it was made by a single developer on his free time. His name was Daisuke Amaya. The fact that this guy is japanese (not that you couldn’t tell it by his name) explains a lot. Like, for starters, game’s setting and plot. Taking place inside giant floating island inhabited by giant sentient rabbit-like creatures called Mimigas this story is both absurd and complex. Starting out very light-hearted game is filled with tremendous amount of jokes. While the story develops, it tends to grow deeper and more brutal than you might think it’ll turn out. Like many metroidvanias do, game prefers not to present you with the world details and backstory, but rather let you explore it by yourself. A vague prologue, which will leave player clueless transits to waking up in a cave. A silent protagonist suffering from memory loss, as cliché as it is, works as perfect instrument here. You wake up, you find a gun, you begin your journey. Your mission, your ultimate goal is covered with the mystery. And discovering it can’t be done separately with finding an answer to an even more important question “What the hell is going on here?” But searching it won’t be similar to aimless wandering around. Cave Story keeps a very good pace, presenting you with new goals and providing directions to them on the go. It isn’t large glowing marker on the map though, but rather clevel organization of levels and progression of the story. Exploring and finding hidden secrets is present in the game, but size of the areas isn’t overwhelming and new levels are introduced one by one. There is though few very unobvious decisions that change the outcome of the game drastically. So if you want to achieve the best ending prepare to keep a keen eye for details or rather even look for some guides. From the perspective of game mechanics it’s the usual run-jump-shoot trio, but with a few twists. One of them is leveling system. Killed enemies drop yellow triangles, which fill the progression bar of currently equipped weapon. Fully filled bar increases weapon level, up to maximum third, but taking damage drops the bar back down, so prepare for some micromanagement. Weapons have different shooting patterns. There is Polar Star which fires plain bullets, then there’s Fireball which produces bouncing deadly balls of fire. Then there’s Spur which has chargeable beam; the longer you charge it, the more powerful the resulting shot will be. Plenty of choices results in very different strategies player can use. Though you’ll tend to have favourites among your arsenal, keeping them all leveled up and ready will be invaluable. To make things even more complex some of the weapons can be traded off in exchange providing you with other guns which have different qualities. This changes are sometimes mutually exclusive and not always reversible, so don’t answer yes every time some friendly NPC offers you something, that’s my advice here. Unlike your main interaction tools your character doesn’t really level up, with the exception of few valuable health upgrades. Not very hard if you keep the default path game is horribly ruthless when it comes to that last levels of the “best ending” branch. How does it sound for you: beating a few sequential levels swarming with enemies and two bosses? If you fail, you start again from the very beginning. That’s very different from the main path, where you’ll find save points after every major event. But then again, it’s for those who want to fully beat the game. For those who are trained and prepared there are even special timer for that last sequence, beating last boss before time runs out will unlock one of the few special music tracks in main menu. The themes depend on how fast you complete it, a new one for each minute saved. And that happens only if you found special secret item, but I guess that won’t be a problem for those who are that deep in the game. Cave Story stands on the shoulders of giants, combining elements from both Metroid and Mega Man. But it goes further than just simple copying of old classics. It is polished and compelling and its influence knows no merits; nearly every modern 2D-metroidvania has taken some lessons from here. A must-have experience if you call yourself a lover of modern indie-games.
It's pretty good for a few hours.

Cave Story is one of the best (Single Player) games I ever played. I brought it for the Wii years back, and really enjoyed it. I got the freeware version on my PC, beat it again, and enjoyed that too. I even played it on my Android device and enjoyed beating it there as well. When I seen Cave Story+ on the market on Steam, I felt like I HAD to add it to my Steam collection by buying it, because, anyone whos finished this game and enjoyed it, can definitely say it deserves a buy. Multiple endings and a fair yet challenging general difficulty is more to ask for in a 2d shooter platformer, it even has extra content and loads of achievements.

I had played the original Cave Story back in 2010, when I read an article about it on 'Hak5'. I liked it 10 minutes into the game, and loved it by the end; when I had had experienced two different endings. 'Multiple endings! Wow!', I thought; and when I read more about it, I found out that there was one another 'best' ending, and some more hidden secrets that I was yet to discover. So I went back to the game, and I did. That was awesome, discovering something new about something that you are already in awe of.   A couple of years forward, I'm playing Cave Story+, with polished graphics, remastered and new music, new game modes, and what not; and I'm totally in love, all over again. Take my word for it, this game is awesome, you will enjoy it to the core. But, if you do like to read more on why I think so, here goes:      Your decisions, and there by your actions will have a bearing on the sort of a game end that you will experience.    You will still discover secrets when playing it for the 'n'th time, there by hugely increasing the game's replay value (provided you don't refer to something similar to 'Cave_Story_Secrets.txt' after the first time, or worse, before you have even completed the game; you will be very very tempted though, and hey, there's no shame in addressing a few guilty pleasures; I always do).     You will love getting lost in a fantastic 2-D world, with beautiful sprites and background art; an awesome score that sets the mood of the area and the situation you are in.    And at last, you will relish, and be in awe of the fact that all of this, from programming; to all the graphics, music; to the big fantastic story in its entirety (which gets revealed in bits, a lot of it through a lot of the characters who are beautifully woven into its strands) was originally conceived by a single guy (who aptly calls himself 'Pixel'). A SINGLE GUY!    Pixel's spirit is that of Hermit Gunsmith, (the drowsy creator of Polar Star; 'What's 'Polar Star'?', you ask! I say, 'Play the game and you shall know.') for he says a few words of wisdom, late into the game, that very much reflect the guy that Pixel is.   'There remains a very delicate balance in this world, between those who create and those who will experience the creations of others. I can't say that I wasn't aware of this. However, I had never experienced it. Now, thanks to you, I finally have. As long as the there is someone who will appreciate the work involved in creation, the effort is time well spent. To this end, I will continue to create for as long as I can.'   - Hermit Gunsmith; Creator, Polar Star & Spur.         Time well spent...

So after years of occupying a place in my Backlog, I finally decided to give Cave Story a shot.  And I can definitely see why people adore this game so much. Playing the game, you can't help but feel the love and hard work put into it, and sometimes its hard to believe this game was made just by one guy.  You could easily place this game alongside indie darlings like Fez, Braid or Super Meat Boy, with its great pixel art and catchy soundtrack, and it's even more incredible to think this came out in 2004, before the indie craze even started.  Every corner of the game is polished and well thought out, so you never get the feeling you are indeed playing a freeware game ( Yes, you can play this game for free, this edition simply includes remastered graphics and soundtrack and some other extras).  As for gameplay, I would call this a '2D Ratchet and Clank', where you have an arsenal of versatile weapons to quickly swap inbetween enemy encounters and platforming segments. The game has a wonderful weapon leveling up system where you can get a stronger version of the weapon you are using if you manage to collect enough power up items dropped by enemies, yet getting hit enough times downgrades it back to regular form. This gives you a sense of feedback, where you feel you are getting rewarded for playing better.  Different kinds of enemies will have you constantly switching weapons in real time to deal with each situation as they come, and the bosses will always have you on the edge of your seat, dodging all kind of attacks and projectiles. You might get the sense at first that this game is a Metroidvania, but you soon realize that levels are very much linear, but there is a ton of secrets and easter eggs to uncover if you like that sort of stuff  The game is fairly accessible while still being very challenging as you go along, and for the hardcore crowd out there, you can try going for the True Ending where you are tasked with beating an incredibly hard level and a Final Boss all in one go without checkpoints, that alone will take you 2-3 hours minimum to beat, unless you are some sort of gaming machine.  As for the story, its a very simple tale that grabs with you with it's charming characters and setting, with a few emotional punches along the way. Nothing complex about it, but its enough to get you invested, and it fits perfectly with the genre and artstyle, and there is depth in it if you are willing to search for it It's very easy to see why Undertale was inspired by this game, taking into account the many parallels between both games.  I'd say definitely play it, you have nothing to lose( literally, it's free if you don't care for extra content). One of the best indie game ever made, and one of the best free games ever made.
Tried 3HP run Almost cried Stuck in hell forever Best platformer ever made 10/10
A nice, original story with cute pixel graphics. The perfect indie game.  Good luck trying to get the best ending however!  10/10

The game is a re-release of Cave Story (Dōkutsu Monogatari), which was introduced 2004 in Japan by Studio Pixel. Later on it got translations into different languages, among them the english version by Aeon Genesis. The english translation in Cave Story+ is done by Nicalis. Now to the differences of these games: Cave Story+ has more content, these would be: - Variety of the difficulty level (Easy, Original, Hard) - Curly Story (main story with Curly Brace as the heroine) - Challenges (5 in total) - Two new dungeons (only to find in challenge mode) - Remastered soundtrack - Improved graphics  To the game itself:  The game is a 2D-platformer, which has rpg, action and adventure elements in it. The 8 bit graphics and sound are very well done and give you the feeling like it was back then in the NES 8 bit era. The gameplay is pretty good and the story makes the game enjoyable every second you play it. You are playing a robot who wakes up in a dark cave with memory loss. Stumbling towards a door that robot finds himself in a village in which the inhabitants are rabbit-like creatures called Mimiga. After hearing the Story of an evil doctor who takes away all Mimiga, the robot decides to investigate the matter and finds out that there's a bigger problem than just a few missing Mimiga. Actually the whole world is in danger and the robot is supposed to stop all evil. We all know that system already, the protagonist has to fix it all.   now my impressions of the game: positive: + remastered and original sound are both available (in most cases the original is in my opinion the better choice) + better graphics (which actually look pretty good, still the old graphics have their own charme) + curly story (even if it is the same story, it's fun to play with her) + hard mode and easy mode (hard mode for those who are searching for a real challenge, easy for those who play the game the first time - you need some time to get used to it after all) + challenge mode (for those who are searching for more challenges)  negative: - achievement-system is a bit broken (in most cases you'll get a major part but some are not to get due to this fact) - replay-function is buggy (broken replays are not what you want in a game after all) - you can only shut down the game via the main menu (the original game gave you this option as soon as you pressed ESC, i think they could have kept it this way) - after a completed challenge in challenge-mode the game will be closed (a bit annoying to start the game all over again) - the game will be closed as soon as you want to see ranks in challenge mode (that's what isn't acceptable, if i buy the game, then i want that it won't kick me out once i choose something in the menu) - in my opinion the english translation by Aeon Genesis was matching the game way better than the one by nicalis  But all in all the negative points aren't that dramatic, the game is worth a recommendation for all people who love classic styled games, a good and very interesting story and for those who enjoy challenges.
A masterpiece of classic platforming

You get to sleep with a bunny-girl-thing and steal an android chick's panties. 10/10, would do it again.     .... besides  that incredible feature, Cave Story is a real love letter to the classic metroidvania and megaman style games, it manages to mix fast paced combat and platforming action, with robust storytelling, and a surprisingly branching story depending on your actions and choices (With 3 distinct endings, as well as alternative game modes, such as playing as the protagonist's partner, with all the appropriate dialogues changes).  The graphics is simple and a call back to older times but remains clean and stylised and doesn't feel like it's being lazy for the sake of calling itself 'retro', it's small cast of characters are well fleshed out for a game of it's genre, and despite it's cute and happy exterior things can get  pretty dark  at times.  With strong replayability and fun, fast paced combat I feel it's certainly worth the tiny price tag. In fact my only criticism is that Cave Story has only 5 dogs, compared to Undertale's 6     Did I mention you can sleep with a mimi... yeah, so, what're you waitting for?
Awesome game with a good soundtrack!

Of course the game is amazing and deserves a purchase. However, Cave Story has a huge glaring issue that you need to be warned about if you've never played.   The game is cryptic as all hell. If you do not follow an extremely specific list of minute tasks (don't talk to this person, talk to this person a second time, examine an object that doesn't appear to be examinable, make this really long jump without falling, don't follow this person until you get this item, etc) then you cannot get the best ending.   I am understandably upset, because even when using a guide, I missed one tiny little step (didn't talk to a person twice) and now the best ending is off limits on my current playthrough. I now have to start all over just because I missed one small step. This cryptic method of game development irritates me to no end and should be left as a relic of the NES era.   Putting all that aside, Cave Story is still one of the best games on Steam and you should buy it rapidly. I just wanted to prepare you for one of the big problems of the game.
I Love This Game.   It's FAR TOO SHORT tho. Some things are ment to be short like.. Short storys... Men's 'Brains' if they own a Jag or Porshe..., Skirts... but NOT CAVE STORY+  Make it longer.

This is a great little platformer. It looks good, it sounds good, it handles well, and it's about as compelling as it needs to be, story-wise. As with many of the platformers of the era it's emulating, I eventually lost interest when I got stuck about where to go next, but I got hours of gameplay out of it, and it was a lot of fun.

This is arguably the best game I've ever played. Just the feel of it ever since I first played it was just too much fun! I've played it through on PC, 3DS, Wii and bought it again on the Nintendo Shop on my 3DS(Classic) and did a hard mode run with the Machine Gun and Bubbline(Pains me to not use king's blade). So I decided, why not buy CS+ as well since it was on sale?! And even though it's like my 3rd time buying it again, I don't think I will ever regret the purchase! Just the diversity and the play style which causes for a tad bit grinding and the punishment system of trying to teach you to not get hit and be tactical. It also has a kind of feel like the game itself is telling you to not give up and be a hero! I mean that is something you almost never see in video games these days.  It also has these really nice transitions of bringing you from upbeat to depressing and it really just shows how a real villian is supposed to act instead of just a clash of ideals and opinions with the whole thing between Misery(Absoloutley <3 Misery she's so casual) and The Doctor(Just a downright jerk) going against Quote and Curly Brace. It just let you feel you were on a real cause instead of it just being a snuff game where the main character was mad the antagonist ♥♥♥♥♥♥ in his corn flakes. It even shows little things where the Villians start to step their game up and try harder instead of just refurbishing their same plan or just sitting back and watching you become OP. Made you feel like: 'Hey, I'm getting stronger, faster and much more cool! I can really do this! Just look at me from start to finish! I started with a dinky pistol, now I'm shooting laser beams while I have stars following me!

THE BEST GAME INDIE EVER! Three awesome endings, amazing metroidvania gameplay, and hard like hell! The game have a great history and a really good OST(the classic or remastered one, both are good)  I've lost hours and hours on this game, recommend a lot to everybody!

A beautiful remake of a fun and challenging game. If you aren't looking to spend the money, you can still find the original as freeware online. Pixel did such an amazing job with this game that I was happy to see it get a remake (though I would suggest waiting until you see it on sale either through Humble Bundle or Steam Sale.. the price tag is rather high for the length of the game).  It's got tight side-scrolling action, wonderful pixel art and soundtrack (particularly the remake), challenging obstacles, multiple endings and unlocks, and a surprising amount of replayability.  It's impressive to think that the original is a decade old and was developed by one man in his free time as freeware.
Fantastic art, music, and story. An excellent homage to the 2D action/exploration games of old.

Cave Story is one of the landmark games in the history of platformers--or in Indie development in general. Developed entirely by Daisuke Amaya (the original, anyway), Cave Story is a grand unification of so many elements within the genre that it's almost the perfect platformer. The gameplay itself is challenging and rewarding, including multiple weapon types, movement modifiers, and levels for each weapon. The characters, storyline, and world are all fully cohesive, interesting, and entirely sympathetic. The music is phenomenal. The art design is retro and charming. It's hard to find anything bad to say about this game at all--so, with that in mind, if you haven't played it, buy this upgraded version right now and treat yourself to one of the best video game experiences of all time.

It has remastered music aswell which is really good. I rate this game 10/10, and I reccomend you buy it right now.

Best platformer/shooter game i've played before. Some parts of this game are pure bullet hell, and other parts are platforming. I can't believe one person made this game, but that adds to the genius of this game. Plenty of things to do, weapons to get and ending to unlock. One of my favorite games.

Story: You play as an amnesic robot named 'Quote' (i guess its from the computer keyboard) who's partner known as 'Curly Brace' is lost.. you find yourself in a cave finding an unfinished but powerful gun from a chest that's owned by a tired gunsmith... then you break open a door and you enter Mimiga Village where Sue (spoiler: she's a human) isn't lending the key to King, then the Mimigas, except a few, are missing and turned into monsters destined to kill anything good/nice... Pros:  Good Graphics, Great Soundtrack, Retro Gameplay, Perfect Controls, Bindable Controls, and the best level design I've ever seen Cons:  The SFX do sometimes get really annoying BCSP: Cave Story Plus is actually a deluxe remake of Doukutsu Monogatari which in English is Cave Story with Better Graphics, Two types of remade soundtracks, more settings, better title screen, and a way better translation Length: 2.5 to 4.5 hours Overall: 9.8/10 (You should definitely buy it...)

If you ask yourself, how many people did it take to make this awesome game, only 1 person made this game literally and its known as the best indie game as of now. Daisuke Amaya also known as Pixel made this game for 5 years during his free time which sounds great. You play the role of a unknown person who wakes up in the first cave, im not joking thats what the 1st level of the game is called. You lookaround the cave and 'steal' a gun from a guy who is sleeping. You soon find yourself in a village called Mimiga Village, a race of bunnies who are kidnapped from the doctor, not the one who helps you with your body i mean the one who kills you for no reason just to possess something. As you progress through the game you find a girl who was a human but got transformed into a mimiga ( dont worry only 2 people got turned like that, every mimiga is not a human) and asks your help to escape the island with her family. You realize you are on a giant island that was a piece of the surface (its not Earth). and that your a robot who was sent to the island to kill the mimiga but you got seperated from your partner and you forgot your name (its a stupid one but im not spoiling that much). Your job in the game is, find your partnet, save the mimiga, rescue the captured mimigas from the docter, kill the docters minions and himself and 1 more thing that affects the entire island. This game is actually harder than it looks as you find missle upgrades, health upgrades, new guns and most importantly, what you must and musnt do. There is 3 ending in the game, bad, ok and good ending. getting the good ending is hard as you must get certain items and not pick up items. I give this game 9 out of 10 because Daisuke Amaya really took his time to make an amazing game all by himself, the music,the gameplay and the graphics. The story gets more interesting as your progress through the game and the gameplay is equevalent to everyone well not the ending as it takes hardcore players to finish. I forgot to mention once you beat the game, you can play as your partner and everything is switch, now the partner is looking for you but its not worth sin e its the exact same thing but with diffrent dialologue.
A must have for retro gamers. Reminiscent of Metroid, Blaster Master, and other simliar classics.

I started the game and immediately saw those Japanese characters. I was like, oh my god, another JRPG, or some other game I don't understand. But I gave it a shot. After couple of minutes, it felt like boring platformer with pixel graphics. Then something changed and I'm still surprised how good is this game.  It is quite complex, story is rich, game has different endings, stages are nonlinear. It is really joy to play. There are even some RPG elements. Weapons are upgradable and they are quite different, so there is time and place for every item from your arsenal. Boss fights are hard, challenging, and most importantly fun. Just more checkpoints would be nice (some traps are instant death).  Highly recommended.
Great game, moving story, awesome soundtrck

Cave Story is probably one of the first PC games that I ever really played. I love the soundtrack, the graphics, the gameplay, and everything else. This makes the game good but when you realize that all of this was done by one man within a course of 5 years, that's when it gets set apart from the other titles like it. The game originally came out as freeware, but now they have improved upon everything that I listed above and made the game that much more enjoyable. Controller support, enhanced soundtrack and better graphics make this game worth its price. It's about time that Pixel gets the money he deserves.  Great game

An indie game that structurally started said movement of the, 'too deep for you,' nonsense that has plagued the majority of indie games alike, consider me surprised when I played it and found it to be amazing.  Gameplay follows a metroidvania element, with environments stemming towards a free-flowing and fluid design that goes heavenly with the soft and twitchy movements that Quote can do. It contrasts a bit, further on, as you obtain the Jetpack, for it breaks the foundation that you maintained for so long, yet the game still makes it able to be introduced to where complications with it aren't lived for too long.  The story follows a set example of amnesia-cased shenanigans, which develops, with the implications and the history provided, into a depressing set of acts that can be only described as brilliant, once acknowledged.   The music fits to the criteria with every given situation, and gives an impact through the gameplay itself that makes it so that actions blend well with the mood of the environment, which gives the player a better understanding of the story without using cutscenes and text to remotely convey it whatsoever. The graphics themselves are sprites of olde time, but alongside the music, adds a vibrant flavor to them that seals the deal, throughout it all.  Although a free version exists, the creator deserves the money for what he has accomplished with such a cute game. It is certainly quite the story, that's for sure.
Awesome game! Scratches that Castlevania/ Mega Man itch. Cute graphics and really well-tuned gameplay.

It's hard for me to explain the joy this game brought to me when I first played through it as a Doukutsu Monogatari (洞窟物語) as freeware.  Buying this game to support Mr. Daisuke Amaya (Pixel) is a great pleasure, and I hope that other people find it in their hearts to buy this game as well.  This game is an updated version of the original Cave Story (which can still be downloaded for free) that features:  Full official translation.  The choice of using updated sprites and music (as well as the original music remastered on PC/Mac). Extra modes and secrets.  I will be hard-pressed to offer another platformer that offers the same depth Cave Story does, and the easiest way to recommend this game is to simply   play the original version and be inspired to purchase this game.  [www.cavestory.org]      Another wonderful game by Mr. Amaya, that is also free.  [www.cavestory.org]

This game. Hoo boy, where do I start.   Well, it came out in the olden days of 2004, and it was entirely free, or a 'free-ware' by definition. Now here we are, with a game that has lived up to its name and praise, with a complete overhaul of the textures to let new generations, including me, to enjoy. I never played it before, and I loved it so much when I first started. Beat it in a day, after restarting everything because, frankly, I screwed up. And now that I've beaten it...I feel lost. I want more like this. I want more games that actually evoke feelings like joy and sadness. Games that make you growl at your computer in ange rbecuase something was just that hard, but that after making it through you breathe for the first time in 50 minutes.  Cave Story is that game. So please. Play it. Enjoy.

Cave Story + is quirky and weird. At first, I thought it was a little too quirky and weird (the first 'boss fight' is against a giant talking handbag), but it quickly grows on you.  There's a varied cast of characters that you grow attached to, a degree of freedom in exploration (although your choices narrow off significantly a number of times), and the story is strangely compelling. The retro aesthetic worked well, and I found I enjoyed the game more when I switched back to the old style sprites (you can choose between old and new graphic elements, and old and new music in the menu), likely due to nostalgia. The game just feels like a forgotten gem from the 8 bit / 16 bit era.  I started out mildly amused but by the end the story was pulling me through (I stopped studying to come and finish the last 2 hours of the game!), the combat mechanics were fun and engaging and I really enjoyed it. Quirky, charming and nostalgic.

Cave Story was the first game I played way back when I first started playing pc games (when I was 5 or 6, so about 11 years ago) when it frist came out as a free downloadable title directly from the site. I loved that game to death. About 2-3 years ago i found out that Cave Story was also on DSiWare and WiiWare, so I quickly bought it on both systems. It was then I realized that the game I played and loved so long ago had a deeper, darker story than what I though it had. Soon after that I lost my DSi, and when I tried to redownload it on my Wii, Nintendo already shut down wifi service for it. I then entered a depressed state, longing to play Cave Story once again...   Then one day, while I was browsing Steam on my Grandma's laptop, I saw it. Cave Story+. I had to look twice, for at first I did not believe the wonderous sight before me. I quickly asked my Grandma if I could buy it, and she said yes.   From then on out, I was happy. I never felt depressed since. My life was complete.
Cave Story+ I recommend that you take the game NOW!

This is going to be in the list of memorable games.  If you're searching for something new, or at least with some variaty, you have to play this. It's unique story makes it really intesting to continue (Even though I'm not a story guy, I still admired it). It's technically one of those games that says: 'Screw reality! Let's go for imagination!', which 95% of all games doesn't do nowadays. Throughout you play the game, you'll confront different entities that you haven't seen before. The first ones are the Mimigas. They also play an important role in the game, so don't forget about them. Later on, you'll confront other types of entities. But remember this: You have never seen them before in your life.  It also have the feel of the old games. It's not really difficult like the old games but it has some of the thinking from the time. For example, there is bosses (Loads of them), no health recharge (All new games has that, and I think games are too easy with it), manual saving (Using save points) and so forth.  But there's one negative side with this game, though. And it's that the story is very involving. And if you know games: The more story it is, the less gameplay. That leaves the player with dialogs and cutscenes where the player doesn't do much other than watching things happen. And what I think about games are that gameplay is the most important thing. Because when I play a game I want to stay in control throughout the whole game. That's what I like with games like Snayke or Doom.  Still, an amazing game. Even though of the negative side, the positive sides overwhelmes that side of the game. I also made a playthrough on this game on YouTube. Here's the link to my montage of my playthrough (If you're still unsure about buying it):         YouTube™ Video:

What started as a freeware platform-adventure game has ended up on Steam in 2011, an enhanced version of the original game Cave Story. This is a great platformer with engaging storyline, unique set of characters, funny and well-written dialogue, an arsenal of inventive weapons, secret chambers, chests and upgrades, humongous range of bosses to fight agains. The game features three different endings and two graphical settings to choose from: original or remastered; as well as three types of soundtrack: original, remastered and brand new one written especially for Wii release of the game. It's worth checking out this game if you have some free time and want to take a break from all the Call of Duties, Medal of Honors and Battlefields.

A fun little indie game. Does it 'invoke classic Metroid'? No. Is it as good as Metroid? No. The only thing it has in common with Metroid is the sound when you grab a health powerup. But for what it is, it is done very well. Indeed the NES could have used more games like this rather than having roughly 90% of its games be complete garbage that I found out through many wasted weekends renting ♥♥♥♥ing trash games when I was younger. This game has great retro graphics and good sound and music, good weapons and enemies, and solid level design. Retro platformers should always be welcome to any gamer with a brain. The only thing that killed this game dead in the water for me was the last battle. You have to fight 4 bosses with 1 life bar and a life full up jar, and it's not that it is hard that gets me, just pure frustration at it's worst. Trust me, beat the first 3 bosses with 1 life bar then use the jar for the final battle. That is your only hope. If you die, you have to do it all over again and go through all the dialogue. It will test even the most dedicated persons patience. There are no words to describe the frustration it causes. Don't get me wrong, I beat it after many tries, but the infinite frustration level still remained. Besides the last battles completely ruining it for me, I liked it.

This version is updated with remixed soundtrack, updated graphics, and extra modes that you can unlock and play. I would recommend playing the free version before purchasing it. Transhumanism. If Cave Story's plot could be put into one word, that would be it. You play as the genocidal robot, Quote. Your mission? Commiting genocide. Your whole body has been replaced by a robot's and you are tasked with the simple and menial task of removing all furry creatures from an island in the sky. The game explores the deep and philosophical questions that an android such as yourself would have after having lost his complete body to a train accident. Along the way, you will befriend many allies, including a couple of human beings, a dragon, and a professor who will manage to upgrade your systems like your creators never imagined. All in all, it has solid gameplay, I played the free version before the steam one came out and I honestly feel bad that the developer only sees a couple of pennies from every game sold, since Nicalis loves to localize games like that.

Cave Story is a well-known game for the people who know such things, and Cave Story+ is a slightly updated edition of that game. However, I am not one those knowledgeable people so for me Cave Story+ was a new acquaintance, and I started the game without knowing anything about it. This was very fitting, because you start the game inside a cave, not knowing anything about where you are, why you are there or even what your name is. Soon you realise that you are inside a huge floating island inhabited by a rabbit people called mimigas. They are in grave danger from a mad scientist, but you believe that you are there to help them. Eventually you start uncovering what is going on, and also who you are.  The plot in the game is rather intricate, so the motivation for the characters is not always obvious. I am not sure that the game constructor himself always knows why the characters act as they do, but since everything is done with such good humour I do not really care.  The game itself is a traditional run, jump, shoot and explore game. The control of the amnesiac main character are intuitive and well behaved. However, it turned out that I was a useless player. In order to progress in the story at a reasonable pace I had to give up my attempt on playing through the game in normal mode and restart everything in easy mode. This, embarrassingly, turned the trousers of the main character yellow. There is a nice selection of weapons that can be obtained through the game, and all types have their uses, so the trouser colour was not too much of a distraction for me in the end.  The graphics and the music are both gloriously retro and happy in style. However, I was surprised to hear Erik Lindström’s fifty-or-so year old 'Letkajenkka' being used as part of the soundtrack. He was sadly not credited in the end titles. This is not how you treat a composer of a catchy song!  Cave Story+ is a very fun game to play and, since there are many choices the player can make through the game and many secrets the player can uncover, it has a large replay value as well. I just wish that my playing skills were on the same level as the game.
If you like Metroid/Castlevania, buy this game right now, before it is not on sale anymore. Awesome

There are three endings, with a lot of variations, and a big challenge to the ones who wants the perfect ending.  For what it is, Cave Story+ is really worth its price. The music is great, the graphics are great, the gameplay is near-perfect, and the whole thing feel so much polished that it could have been made by professionals. HD maniacs can go in (Running) Hell for all I care, this game is better than a lot of recent games I've played. While the game isn't perfect, it certainly gives a sight of what a perfect game could be.

I think someone called this 'the best Super Nintendo game never made,' and I pretty much agree. It's plenty hard without being crushing, which is a tough line for a developer to negotiate. It's the kind of game where you can figure out what's going your way and what isn't, and adjust your approach accordingly. It also has accessible controls. Where I would normally avoid platformers on PC, this game is entirely playable on a computer platform.  The one thing I disliked about 'Cave Story' was how certain branch points were governed by choices that weren't possible to 'intuit.' For instance, getting the best weapon in the game and saving a certain character are prevented by simply deciding to do things that make perfect sense at an earlier time. I really am not a fan of fundamental gameplay elements being closed off by way of 'you need a game guide to figure this out, because you would never guess that this choice would be so Earth-shattering.'  Even with that major gripe, though, this game really is fantastic. It's a beautifully made nod to the old traditions of gaming, and its charm is really hard to deny.
I strongly suggest this game. It's up there with Bleed for my favorite side scroller.

If this is your first time hearing about Cave Story, its basically a metroidvania style action platformer. It has a really nice retro pixel art aesthetic and boasts a fantastic soundtrack. Despite being a solo effort and originally free, the game is actually pretty long and has a lot of content. There is a large array of fun weapons, ranging from a laser pistol to a leathal bubble gun, as well as many upgrades for you to find. I highly recommend this game, its so much fun.

CaveStory is one of those games that I had always heard people always talk about fondly, but I never really gave it a shot. I got the game about two years ago on the 3DS and I found it a little too hard, so I just kinda let it sit for a while, until somebody gifted the Plus version to me on steam. It took me a while to install it, and thats because I had fallen in love with the 3DS version, and even got the best ending, and even got to that point on hard mode (Still havent beaten Hell though)!  After installing Cave Story+, I found there is pretty much nothing differn't aside from the graphics update, and thats because its literally the same game, so it makes sense. Anyway I've got to say this is my prefered version of the game, and is the one I keep coming back to. Its the perfect blend of a great platformer, challenging levels, stages and boss fights, and many, MANY deaths. None of this is bad though, because no matter how many times I ended up screaming at the game, it just made me happy, that there is a game out there, that gives you an urge to beat it, the more you die.  So! If you like games that offer a good challenge, a bunch of weapons, a truly unique level-up system, and an addorible cast, then Cave Story, Cave Story+ or whatever version you want to play, is right for you!  (Sorry for any spelling mistakes, its almost 1 AM at the time I'm typing this.)

The original Cave story with options built into the main menu, an easy and hard mode, updated graphics and music and different character sprites that I hear are dependent upon the season.  The new music doesn't have the same old charm but a couple of the tracks do sound better. The graphics are a major improvement over the original, so much so that it makes the game feel different. Both the new music and graphics can be disabled, which is very good. Quote's new appearance is disappointing and I wish I could change it back to the original.  There is an actual menu now so you don't have to use a seperate program to configure the game. Generic gaming controllers are supported by default so it isn't necessary to fool around with a profiler. I recommend using a keyboard anyway. Still no mouse support for any of the menus but there is a custom pointer. There are hardly any display options. Just windowed, fullscreen, sharp, and stretch. No preset resolutions but you can just resize the window with your mouse.  Hard mode enforces a classic challenge to complete the game without picking up any precious health expansion items by removing them entirely. A good feature to have. There are challenge levels that you can access from the main menu as well.  Game was great. Now it's better and costs money. If you haven't played the original do yourself a favor and pick this up right now.

Whilst looking through some old humble indie bundles, I found Cave Story+ sitting there among many other games, untouched. I couldn't recall even purchasing a bundle containing it, but a game is a game, and I promptly loaded it up on Steam.  I recall a hype surrounding the game some time back, and never really payed much attention to it as I don't with such things. So when I hit the menu screen, I had no expectations. The game I found myself playing had jumping. Soon there was a pistol, and then a rocket launcher. There were bosses and strange rabbit-like animals. I was having a blast. The controls were responsive, it had a nice skill ceiling, there were items to collect and I found myself somehow interested in it's simplistic story.  Cave Story+, an update on the base game (which is free, to my knowledge), found a niche I didn't know I enjoyed, and interested me to other games not dissimular from it. If I could level any criticism, it would be the arbitrary conditions required to get the 'Good ending'. I won't spoil it, but they can be rather silly. Still, I enjoyed my time with the game and recommend it heartily.

I say I recommend this game, but I say so with a warning. Don't get me wrong, the gameplay is smooth, the weapons are fun to use, the platforming is challenging but not too frustrating, and the story is original, creative and enjoyable. There are many different enemies, all with different attack patterns, and all the bosses are fun to beat. 9 times out of 10 I would recommend this game to friends.  However, there's one issue - the endings.  I'm the type of person that doesn't really want to look things up while I play a game. I want to play the game, try my best to find all the secrets/powerups/etc., and if I miss a few, I'm fine with it.  However, if Cave Story, there are certain points in the game where if you do one thing over another, or pick up one item over another, etc. it will change the entire course of the game. I, not using the internet and not knowing this, played the game as it seemed I should play it, and got to the 'normal' ending.  And frankly, the 'normal' ending is depressing and disappointing.  Upon looking it up after beating the game, I discovered there were two more satisfying, exciting endings to the game, that I had missed by doing X during the story, and I wasn't about to go play the entire story again.  Cave Story's mechanics are good and the regular story is great until you get to the end. If you're fine with looking up walkthroughs and secrets as you play a game, I highly recommend this game. If not, I might think twice about getting Cave Story, as the ending will disappoint you.

An amazing experience, Cave Story plays its cards perfectly. The weapon leveling concept is an interesting little way of making players want to avoid tanking hits and seeing each weapon's various levels was something that I looked forward to each time. The music is simple, catchy, and just fits perfectly. Being a platformer, control is important and cave story excels in this providing simple controls with satisfying precision. The look of the game is charming and the simple sprite-based style works extremely well for a simple game with simple charm

Cave Story+ is a very charming side-scrolling platformer/shooter. Many of the characters are quite humorous and loveable. The game is challenging, though not frustratingly so (at least for the most part). There are also several challenge modes and difficulty levels for those who want variety. The game also has quite a sense of humor. For example, when choosing a difficulty level, there's an option to confirm and cancel. When you put the cursor on Hard, the word cancel changes to 'I'm too scared!' There are other funny moments in the game itself, as well as some touching moments. Also the music is some of my favorite. There are a few versions of the soundtrack, but I personally prefer the retro version. Overall, this game is definitely worth it to buy!

It's a wonderful mix of a core Metroid style gameplay, complete with exploration elements, with a dash of Mega Man feel to it.  The graphics have received a modest upgrade from the original release, and you have the option to enable the original visuals if you prefer them to the slightly improved versions.  The gameplay shines in titles like this. While the beginning areas don't seem like much to explore, there are a lot of hidden little nooks and crannies stuffed with goodies and powerups for your trouble.  Even from the start the story is interesting and the characters imaginative. I found myself wanting to know more about both.  The art and character style reminds me of games like Mega Man Legends, Maple Story, perhaps even Pokemon to a degree, but presented in what is essentially an 8-bit style action platformer that emphasizes progression via exploration.  If you enjoy so-called 'Metroidvania' style games, you'll definitely want to check this one out.

9/10 First time I ever loved a platformer. Cave Story is the brilliant child of Studio Pixel, a one-man company. Pixel spent five years developing Cave Story in his free time. There's a lot of TLC put into the design, and it really does show. Now I sucked at platforming going into this game. I just did not have the skillset. This game gave me the necessary skills to succeed in a platformer, and really ramped it up as I neared the True Ending. The music was awesome, and in Cave Story+, You get three choices of soundtrack: Original: From the freeware version of the PC game New: From the EU patch of the Nintendo WiiWare port of the game Remastered: From the fully-3D Nintendo 3DS remake of the game. The graphics can also be in their lesser Original quality, or their newly refined Remastered quality. This game has a lot of wonderful elements, and you'll likely log HOURS of gameplay in this game. The Soundtrack, in whichever form, is catchy, and you'll definitely jam out to it. With all said, I give this game a 9/10, docking points nly for the sudden intensity spike for activating the true ending's route, granted it was to be expected

I own 3 versions of this (including this), have beaten it about 8 times, and have put over 150 hours into this game. I'll just presume you read the game description and cut to the chase. This is a high replay value action platformer taking high inspiration from Metroid. No, it is not Metroidvania, it's pretty linear. There are many different weapons to pick. Some weapons require trading weapons for others, some require you to combine 2, and so on. There are 3 endings for this game. Don't listen to what the description says, THERE ARE 3 ENDINGS. The first ending is pretty much the bad ending, it's more of a game over than anything else. The second ending is probably the one you'll do first on your own, it's not that hard to do and straightforward. The 3rd ending you WILL need Internet help from, there's a lot of weird things you have to do that you would never think of. This isn't that long of a game, and the freeware version is just the story, that's it. In this version: you have 3 save files for the story mode, 3files for a mode where you play as another character, 5 time-attack challenges, easy and hard modes, and improved graphics and music. Is the $10 worth the improvements? Yes! Should you try out the original freeware first just in case? Why not? It's free. Final note: this game is VERY hard for beginners. I recommend easy mode for beginners. Once you play as many hours as me, normal mode isn't hard at all, and easy mode is a breeze (once beat the entire game in easy on the second ending without dying once). hard mode is hard for everyone. You get no extra life capsules, and no rocket launchers. Very difficult. Sorry, this was more of a information ramble than a review. Anyways, this gets a solid 8.7 for me.

Chances are that if you like platformers, then at some point in your life you've probably heard of Cave Story. That's because it really is one of the best.  The platforming is superb. While it can be difficult to get the hang of controlling your character at first, it becomes easier  quickly   eventually  after a few dozen deaths. There are several different weapons to collect during your adventure, and no, it's not possible to have all of them in one playthrough. The level design is excellent, enemy attacks are simple to learn but can still provide challenge, and while the art style and music are always up to individual preference, I've never heard anyone say that the soundtrack was anything less than excellent. But what really makes this game special is its heart. That makes it difficult to review, of course, but if you're still divided, just look at the steam review scores. Or heck, anyone's review scores. The game is good, people.  A word to the wise: the game is also difficult, even for a platforming buff like me. If you're not a regular platformer, choose the easy difficulty - having played through the original difficulty and aiming to get the 'secret' ending, I can promise that I did not always feel as fondly about the game as I do now.

One of the greatest and most influential games of all time, with one of the most unnecessary remakes of all time.   At best the additions are novel. Most of the songs in the 'remastered' soundtrack are fine, but not better than the original. There are added difficulty modes that just change the amount of health you have, and while the easy mode is good for inexperienced players the game's difficulty curve was already very well crafted in the first place. Hard mode just forces you to not pick up any health upgrades, something simple to do if you wanted to impose it on yourself in the original. The other extra game modes are not substantial.  At worst the 'additions' actually detract from the experience. One of the 3 optional soundtrack options is an abomination. The extra fidelity on the sprites is often a step backward: you can see a more of some characters' facial features but their expressions never change so it looks soulless. Their official translation often feels like it was trying too hard not to be the original fan translation, adding some cheap jokes and removing classic lines.   The only circumstance where I would reccomend you get this version of the game is if you want to support the developer who spent 5 years making the original and released it for free. Even then, I don't know how much money actually goes to him and not the company who took a free game and made a bunch of unwanted changes just so they could charge people for it.  If you do end up playing this version of the game first, play it with the included options for original soundtrack and art. You can try the updated visuals and music on your inevitable repeat playthrough, because you will love this game.  It's sad when the best way to play a premium version of the game is to emulate the free version as closely as possible.

EDIT/UPDATE: It has very recently come to my attention that Nicalis has decided to raise the price of the game from $9.99 to $14.99. In addition to this, it seems that Nicalis has also decided to not put the game on anymore sales, and from what I have heard, there hasn't been anything done to the game content-wise that could justify this. In other words, Nicalis has decided to raise the price just to gain more money. I can no longer see any reason to purchase this version of Cave Story, as I mentioned in my original review (which will still be posted below this paragraph) that there isn't enough content to justify a full price purchase of this particular version. Instead of purchasing this version of the game, I advise that you just go and download the freeware version of the game, as you will be saving a whole lot of money just downloading the freeware version than by buying an overpriced version of a game that, while good, isn't worth $14.00. $9.99 was already steep, but increasing the price without even adding any content to justify it is pathetic. Don't give Nicalis your money.    ORIGINAL POST: Despite starting one of the worst trends in gaming (indie gaming, to be more exact), Cave Story is actually a pretty damn good game made by just a single person. Of course, with that being said, I suggest that you play the original freeware version of the game first before using your money to buy Cave Story +, as this particular version of the game isn't much different from the original freeware game, save for some bonus content and some minor improvements. If you do decide that you want to purchase this version of the game, do wait a little to see if it goes on sale, as I don't think that there is enough content to justify a full-price purchase of this version of the game.
